issues.description: Template repository contains a malformed and incorrectly named Farm implementation: template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java defines a class named AnimalFarm (and even contains a duplicate package/class declaration nested inside a method), while the problem statement and solution expect a class named Farm with the methods/constructors shown in the UML. This makes the template uncompilable and prevents students from implementing or testing the intended design (e.g., Main.java attempts to create a Farm instance).
issues.suggested_fix: Replace the malformed template file with a correct Farm class skeleton that matches the UML and the solution structure. At minimum: (1) Rename the public class to Farm (public class Farm { ... }) and remove any nested package/class declarations or duplicate top-level declarations; (2) Provide the animals attribute (List<Animal> animals), a no-arg constructor that initializes the ArrayList, and method stubs with correct signatures: getAnimals(), setAnimals(List<Animal>), addAnimal(Animal), feedAllAnimals(), singFarmSong(), and a private helper singFarmSongVerse(Animal). Ensure the class name and API match the UML/problem statement so Main.java and student implementations compile and run.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution refer to a class named 'Farm', but the template file template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java declares the class as 'AnimalFarm'. Additionally, the provided template Main.java expects a class named 'Farm' (it instantiates 'new Farm()'). This mismatch (class named AnimalFarm in a file named Farm.java) breaks the expected one-to-one mapping between the exercise description and the starter code, will cause compile errors, and forces students to reconcile two different identifiers for the same conceptual entity.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the class in the template from 'AnimalFarm' to 'Farm' (and ensure the public class name matches the filename Farm.java). Also remove any duplicated/malformed content in the template file so that the class declaration is 'public class Farm { ... }'. This aligns the template with the problem statement and the solution, avoiding compile errors and reducing student confusion.
